accomodations.about: A suburb in the lower north shore of Sydney. As there are several buildings heritage-listed it makes it a beautiful place to wander about, providing you a “historic” vibe.  Local spots are the Greenwood Plaza, the Greenwood Hotel and Milson’s Point where you can walk across the Harbour Bridge into central Sydney.
accomodations.directions: If your focus is solely being close in proximity to the wedding location, this is the best option. It’s north of the harbour reducing your travel time immensely but still accessible to Sydney central.

accomodations.about: A neighbourhood made up of historic laneways in the shadow of Sydney Harbour Bridge. The area has some of Sydney’s oldest pubs and restaurants with harbour views as  it was the first place of English settlement in Australia. Local spots are Museum of Contemporary Art, The Rocks Markets, The Glenmore pub, The Australian pub, history tours and selection of other activities. This area will be the most expensive option for accommodation.
accomodations.directions: This is the best option if you want to be midway between the wedding location and central city. It is the first neighbourhood over the harbour

accomodations.about: Neighbourhood located at the southern end of the central business district. Home of the largest railway station in New South Wales. It’s also known for converted warehouses and a creative scene. Local spots include galleries around Abercrombie Street, Seymour Centre, plenty of places to eat and drink and easy access to all neighbouring suburbs.
accomodations.directions: If your focused on staying pretty central in the city this is your best option.

accomodations.about: An area you may associate the word “hipster” with, well known for its trendy inhabitants. Crown and Cleveland streets sport awesome coffee joints, fashion boutiques and eateries from all over the world. Local spots include any pub, any café, any wine bar and any gallery.
accomodations.directions: Again, if you’re focused on staying pretty central Sydney this is your best (and nicest) option.

accomodations.about: The most famous beach of the Northern Beaches. The beach was named by Captain Arthur Phillip. The Corso, a pedestrian plaza consists of shops, coffee joints, cafes and bars. Great coastal spot for shopping and dining. Local spots also include visiting the neighbouring beaches Fairy Bower and Shelley Beach. Good location if you want to avoid the hustle and bustle of Sydney central.
accomodations.directions: Quite easy to get to the wedding location as it’s on the same side of the harbour. Best option to go via a car.

attractions.summary: There is more to do than the day is long here Sydney. As you are planning your stay, here are a few iconic tourist attrications for you to consider.

food.summary: Here are some of our favorite places to eat in the city. If you are new to the city, we highly encourage you to take on this map as a way to taste your way through the city.

locations.name: Gelato Messina
locations.address: Surry Hills, 389 Crown St, Surry Hills
locations.details: A must visit if you care at all for creamy treats. There are multiple locations around this city, but this is our favorite

locations.name: Chinese Noodle House
locations.details: This gem lies in the heart of china town. Bring cash and prepare to wait in line -- its worth it.

locations.name: Bourke Street Bakery
locations.details: Bourke St Bakery offers a wide selection of pasteries, but be sure to try the meat pies and the sausage rolls

locations.name: Kepos Street Kitchen
locations.details: If you are after a stellar Aussie breakfast, this mediterranean fusion cafe hits the spot every time.

locations.name: The Grounds of Alexandria
locations.details: When I asked Pat why he recommends this, he replied `It's just dope!`... so you should check it out.

locations.name: Via Napoli Pizzaria
locations.details: 2 meter pizza from a brick oven made with amazing ingredients makes for a great option for a family style meal.
